instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.C1803: What is C1803? Capacitor to ground on RTC_RESET_L on machines from 2009-2012, RTC_RESET_L needs to be high for system to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message:
board wont turn on and had very noticeable water damage. replaced whatever was badly damaged and retraced some areas. i get a green light on charger.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>=.600v

something is pulling s4 down correct?

tried comparing the board with a known good but could not find any obvious differences besides <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> being low.

what should i look for?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message: Need to know is PPBUS present, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>? Voltage on <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03, crap under SMC likely.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message:
ppbus is present
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> is present
<CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR> is 3.0v
<CAPACITOR>C1803</CAPACITOR> is 3.042v

i removed smc and area looks clean

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message: Clock chip replaced if liquid was there? Any sign of power cycling?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message:
i just replaced a bunch of components in that area including clock chip because it was water damaged. now i get 3.3v on <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03
as far as power cycling no
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> still .600v and drops.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message: Could be so many things now. Was there corrosion around the PCH? Checked all rails for shorts? What SMC did you put back on?
